tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This refers to a man who is afflicted. AT: "the afflicted man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"faint" or "weak"

tn.ref: pours out his lament before Yahweh
tn.text: The way the author expresses his lament is compared to pouring out a liquid. AT: "freely expresses his grief to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: my days pass away like smoke
tn.text: Here "my days" refers to the author's life and the idea of "smoke" is something that quickly disappears. AT: "my life passes away quickly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here the author refers to his "body" as his "bones." AT: "my body feels like it is burning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

Here the author refers to himself as his "heart." This can be stated in active form. AT: "I am in despair" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: I am like grass that has withered
tn.text: This is another way to describe his despair. AT: "I feel like I am drying up like withered grass" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: I am like a pelican of the wilderness
tn.text: He compares his loneliness to that of a  pelican, which is often seem alone instead of with other birds. AT: "I am lonely and despised like a pelican in the wilderness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a large fish-eating bird

tn.ref: I have become like an owl in the ruins
tn.text: The author continues to describe loneliness by comparing himself to an owl in abandoned ruins. AT: "I have become alone like an owl in abandoned ruins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This is a bird that is awake at night. AT: "a night bird"

tn.ref: I lie awake like a solitary bird
tn.text: The writer compares himself to a bird to emphasize his feeling of loneliness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

David would have sat in ashes as an act of mourning, therefore ashes would have fallen on his food. AT: "I eat ashes like I eat bread" or "As I mourn, ashes fall on the bread that I eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: and mix my drink with tears
tn.text: David did not purposefully mix his drink with tears; rather his tear would have fallen into his cup while he mourned and wept. AT: "and my tears fall into the cup that I drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: you have lifted me up to throw me down
tn.text: God has not literally lifted and thrown David's body to the ground; rather David says this to describe what he is feeling and experiencing. AT: "it is like you have lifted me up to throw me down" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: My days are like a shadow that fades
tn.text: David compares his time left to live on earth to a fading shadow. AT: "My time to remain alive is short like an evening shadow that will soon be gone" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

As David's body becomes weak and he is nearing the end of his life, he compares himself to withering grass. AT: "my body has become weak like withered grass" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
dry and wrinkled

tn.ref: your fame is for all generations
tn.text: "you will be recognized for all generations to come"
being known by many people
Here "Zion" refers to the people who live in Zion. AT: "have mercy on the people of Zion" (See: Metonymy)
The word "her" refers to Zion.

The "stones" refer to the stones that were part of the city walls before they were destroyed. AT: "still love the stones that were formerly in the city walls" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "your name" refers to Yahweh. AT: "you" (See: Metonymy)
The people will honor Yahweh because of his glory. Here Yahweh is referred to by his glory. AT: "will honor you because you are glorious" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"will be seen as glorious" or "people will see his glory"
This refers to destitute people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: he will not reject their prayer
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "Yahweh will accept their prayers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: This will be written for future generations
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I will write this for future generations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: For he has looked down from the holy heights; from heaven Yahweh has viewed
tn.text: These two phrases have similar meaning and are used together for emphasize how God looks down from heaven. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"his holy place high above the earth"

tn.ref: those who were condemned to death
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "those whom the authorities had sentenced to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: proclaim the name of Yahweh in Zion and his praise in Jerusalem
tn.text: These two phrases have the same meaning and emphasize the idea of praising the name of Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
The missing words may be added. AT: "and proclaim his praise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

David describes God causing him to become weak as if his strength were a physical item that could be taken away from him. AT: "has caused me to become weak" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "days" here refers to his life. AT: "my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
David is asking God to not let him die. AT: "do not take me away from the earth" (UDB) or "do not let me die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you are here throughout all generations
tn.text: "you are present throughout all generations"
The word "they" refers to "the earth" and "the heavens."

tn.ref: your years will have no end
tn.text: Here David describes the length of time that God is alive as his "years." This can be written in positive form. AT: "you will live forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
"will continue to live"
Here David describes the descendants being protected  by Yahweh as being in his presence. AT: "be protected as they live in your presence" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
